unnormalised: Okay, so you're trying out that new paneer butter masala recipe, huh? Awesome! But let's make sure we get the measurements right, okay? No one wants a watery sauce or paneer that's drier than the Thar Desert.
normalised: Okay, so you're trying out that new paneer butter masala recipe, huh? Awesome! But let's make sure we get the measurements right, okay? No one wants a watery sauce or paneer that's drier than the Thar Desert.

unnormalised: First things first: the paneer. You'll need about 250 gm, give or take. Honestly, a little more won't hurt. Just cube it into bite-sized pieces, around 1.5 cm each. Don’t go too small, they'll just disintegrate in the sauce.
normalised: First things first: the paneer. You'll need about two hundred and fifty gram, give or take. Honestly, a little more won't hurt. Just cube it into bite-sized pieces, around one point five centimeter each. Don’t go too small, they'll just disintegrate in the sauce.

unnormalised: Now for the base of the masala, we're talking tomatoes. Aim for about 400 grams. That’s roughly 3-4 medium-sized ones. Dice them up nice and fine, or even better, blitz them in a mixer. Smooth sauce is key!
normalised: Now for the base of the masala, we're talking tomatoes. Aim for about four hundred grams. That’s roughly three to four medium-sized ones. Dice them up nice and fine, or even better, blitz them in a mixer. Smooth sauce is key!

unnormalised: Butter! Ah, the star of the show. Don't skimp! We’re going with about 50 g of Amul butter. If you want a richer taste, feel free to add another 25 gm. No one's judging!
normalised: Butter! Ah, the star of the show. Don't skimp! We’re going with about fifty gram of Amul butter. If you want a richer taste, feel free to add another twenty five gram. No one's judging!

unnormalised: Onions are next. 2 medium-sized, which is around 150 grams, will do the trick. Finely chop them and fry 'em till they're golden brown. Trust me, this step is crucial for that deep, caramelized flavor.
normalised: Onions are next. two medium-sized, which is around one hundred and fifty grams, will do the trick. Finely chop them and fry 'em till they're golden brown. Trust me, this step is crucial for that deep, caramelized flavor.

unnormalised: Ginger-garlic paste – the backbone of Indian cooking. Use about 1 tbsp, which is roughly 15 grams. Freshly ground is always best, but the store-bought stuff works in a pinch too.
normalised: Ginger-garlic paste – the backbone of Indian cooking. Use about one tablespoon, which is roughly fifteen grams. Freshly ground is always best, but the store-bought stuff works in a pinch too.

unnormalised: Spices! This is where it gets fun. For chili powder, start with 1 tsp (around 5 gm). Adjust to your spice level, obviously. Kashmiri chili powder gives a great colour without too much heat. Then we have garam masala- ½ tsp should do it. Turmeric powder- ¼ tsp will give it that yellow hue. And for the coriander powder, use 1.5 teaspoons. Don’t forget to add salt according to your taste.
normalised: Spices! This is where it gets fun. For chili powder, start with one teaspoon (around five gram). Adjust to your spice level, obviously. Kashmiri chili powder gives a great colour without too much heat. Then we have garam masala- half teaspoon should do it. Turmeric powder- a quarter teaspoon will give it that yellow hue. And for the coriander powder, use one point five teaspoons. Don’t forget to add salt according to your taste.

unnormalised: Cream is what makes the dish velvety! 100ml of Amul fresh cream! If you are using a thicker cream, reduce the quantity by 20ml.
normalised: Cream is what makes the dish velvety! one hundred milliliter of Amul fresh cream! If you are using a thicker cream, reduce the quantity by twenty milliliter.

unnormalised: Finally, just a splash of kasuri methi, about 1 tsp. Crush it between your palms before adding it, that really wakes up the flavour. And for serving, a handful of chopped coriander leaves. Like, 2 tbsp or so.
normalised: Finally, just a splash of kasuri methi, about one teaspoon. Crush it between your palms before adding it, that really wakes up the flavour. And for serving, a handful of chopped coriander leaves. Like, two tablespoon or so.

unnormalised: Now, if you want to make it restaurant-style, a tiny pinch (like 0.25 g) of orange food colouring works wonders for that vibrant colour. But that's totally optional! Remember, cooking is all about experimenting! Good luck, and happy cooking!
normalised: Now, if you want to make it restaurant-style, a tiny pinch (like zero point two five gram) of orange food colouring works wonders for that vibrant colour. But that's totally optional! Remember, cooking is all about experimenting! Good luck, and happy cooking!
